title.q: The Fiend of the Forest Fire

editionStmt.edition: Transcribed and edited by Leon Prenter and Philip Steer

publicationStmt.publisher: The Braidwood Dispatch and Mining Journal

sourceDesc.bibl: Buckenboura. The Fiend of the Forest Fire. The Braidwood Dispatch and Mining Journal, 25 May 1889, p. 4.

projectDesc.p: Transcribed and encoded as part of Settler Literature and Environmental Change in Australia and New Zealand, Marsden Fund Standard Grant 19-MAU-022 (Te Apārangi Royal Society of New Zealand).

lg.l: Straight down from the heavens of brass,
In the glare and the gleam of its ray,
The sun seemed to scorch up the grass
And to wither the waters away;
Even back in the desolate hills
No sign of a moisture was left,
High mountains had weaned all the rills
Till gorges and glens were bereft;
Far back in the belt of the brush
Bold dingoes were drinking the blood
Of the cattle knocked down in the crush
For the hole that was miry with mud.
High smoke from the hills and the haze,
Of the heat in the hell of its glare,
Enveloped the sun till its rays
Looked red in the glass of the air.
Then famine and fever and worse
Soon ran in a riot abroad,
For a fiend came down like a curse
That was sent by the hand of the Lord.
Three days did the pall of a smoke
Drift forth in its darkness so dire,
Till the blaze o'er each barrier broke
To follow the fiend of the fire. Fire. The Braidwood Dispatch reported on 29 August 1888 that The district in all directions is ablaze (p. 1).
From the far away rills of the north,
Right down to the range of the south,
This fiend in his fury sped forth
To finish the work of the drought.
With the roar of a volcanic flame
When the pot hissing lava is hurled,
Like a bolt from Gehenna Gehenna. Hell, or the place of future torment. it came,
To burn up a beautiful mould.
Deavouring with ravenous maw,
Borne on by a bellowing wind,
It flew in its fury before
And left only ashes behind,
Waxing great in its grip of the belt,
Of the brush and the scrub of the coast;
But the worst of its fury was felt
By far away farmers the most;
Where the stringy bark Stringy bark. The bark of the eucalyptus, or gum tree. tied on the hut,
(For such are the wilderness ways)
On the timber that had been cut
Was ready to burst into blaze.
There many a son of the soil,
With his wife and child had to fly,
While the whole of their many years’ toil
Went up with the smoke to the sky.
Thick ashes and smoke in the air
Made day seem as dark as the night,
And night was made day with the flare
Of the flame in its furious flight.

l.q: Oh, God, send us speedily rain

lg.l: All preachers in pulpits implore,
But the prayer of the people in vain
Was heard for a fortnight or more.
Then Pluvius Pluvius. The sender of rain, a surname of Jupiter, to whom Romans offered sacrifices during times of drought. harnessed his car
To the wings of a southerly gale,
And volleyed at Vulcan Vulcan. The Roman god of fire. afar,
Who hissed at the lash of his nail,
Till the demon that danced in the drought
Fell back at the fall of much rain,
And the fiend of the forest, starved out,
Slunk back into Hades Hades. Hell, or the abode of the dead. again.

body.p: BUCKENBOURA. Buckenboura. The penname invokes the local Parish of Buckenbowra.
